contextId.information: These two clauses describe the darkness of the day of Job's birth, thus repeating Job's regret that he had been born. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: May that day be dark ... neither may the sun shine on it

contextId.information: These phrases express the same idea in a different way. They convey the idea that Eliphaz heard a message whispered to him. This repetition is a form of Hebrew poetry used frequently for emphasis, teaching, or clarity. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Now a certain matter was secretly brought to me ... my ear received a whisper about it

contextId.information: This two phrases have the same meaning. They describe how the streambed is full ice and snow in the winter. AT: "in the winter they look dark because they are covered with ice and are full of melted snow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: which are darkened because of ice over them ... and because of the snow that hides itself in them

contextId.information: These two phrases have the same meaning. They describe how the streambed dries up in the hot season. AT: "but when it is hot, the ice melts and the streambeds dry up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: When they thaw out, they vanish ... when it is hot, they melt out of their place

contextId.information: Here Job conveys a single idea using two different rhetorical questions to emphasize his wish that God would stop watching him. AT: "Look away from me! Leave me alone long enough for me to swallow my own saliva!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[ en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How long will it be ... swallow down my own saliva?

contextId.information: Here Job uses two similar clauses within a rhetorical question to emphasize his point. Possible meanings are: 1) Job is asking why God does not forgive him. AT: "Tell me why you do not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity." or 2) Job is asking God why he cannot just overlook his supposed wrongdoings. AT: "Tell me why you do not just bear with my transgression and iniquity." See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity?

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the godless person is trusting in something that cannot save him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: His confidence will break apart ... his trust is as weak as a spider's web

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meaning, but the meaning is unclear. Possible meanings are 1) he appears to be well-rooted in the rocks, taking advantage of every opening or 2) his roots cannot find fertile ground and must try to find nutrients among the rocks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His roots are wrapped about the heaps of stone ... they look for good places among the rocks

contextId.information: These two phrases have nearly the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: your days like the days of mankind ... your years like the years of people

contextId.information: These two phrases have nearly the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: inquire after my iniquity ... search after my sin

contextId.information: The impossibility of understanding God is spoken of as if it were impossible to go to these extremely far away places. AT: "is as inaccessible as the highest places in heaven ... is more inaccessible than the deepest places in Sheol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: is as high as heaven ... deeper than Sheol

contextId.information: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: You would be secure ... take your rest in safety

contextId.information: These 4 statements all express the idea that the beasts, the birds, the earth, and the fish understand God better than Job's friends do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: But now ask ... will declare to you.

contextId.information: These two questions are basically the same and are used together to emphasize that a man cannot be perfect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: What is man ... What is he who is born

contextId.information: These two lines are a variation to each other and are used together to emphasize how desperate Job is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I have said to the pit ... and to the worm

contextId.information: These phrases together emphasize the fact that the wicked person will be sent to Sheol, the place of the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He will be driven from light into darkness ... and be chased out of this world

contextId.information: Together these two phrases emphasize that he will have no family or descendants left. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He will have no son ... nor any remaining kinfolk where he had stayed

contextId.information: Here "fly away" and "be chased away" represent disappearing. They may also imply being forgotten, since dreams and visions disappear when people forget them. AT: "He will disappear like a dream ... he will be forgotten like a vision of the night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He will fly away like a dream ... he will be chased away like a vision of the night

contextId.information: These phrases mean the same thing because "eyes" refers to sight. Wicked people get to watch their descendants grow strong and wealthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in their sight ... before their eyes

contextId.information: Both of these phrases mean that the person is very healthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: His body is full of milk ... the marrow of his bones is moistened and in good health

contextId.information: Eliphaz is accusing Job of taking land from poor people and not allowing them to live on it. He is emphasizing this point by restating it twice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: possessed the earth ... lived in it

contextId.information: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize Job's desire to meet with God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Oh, that I knew where ... Oh, that I might come

contextId.information: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize Job's desire to explain his situation to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I would lay my case ... fill my mouth

contextId.information: These two lines mean basically the same thing and emphasize Job's desire to hear God's answer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I would learn the words ... what he would say to me

contextId.information: These two lines describe the same thing and are used together to emphasize that these people are so hungry that they are forced to steal food at night. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Poor people reap in the night ... they glean grapes

contextId.information: These two questions are used together to emphasize that it is impossible for a man to be good enough for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: How then can man ... God? How can he who is born ... him?

contextId.information: These two lines say the same thing and are used together to emphasize that man is not perfect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: How much less man ... a son of man, who is a worm

contextId.information: The two clauses that start with these words share the same meaning. They are used together to emphasize Job's strong desire that this should happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Let my enemy be ... let him who rises up against me be

contextId.information: These clauses express similar meaning. AT: "No bird of prey or falcon knows or has ever seen the path that goes to the mine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: No bird of prey knows the path to it ... nor has the falcon's eye seen it

contextId.information: These clauses also express similar meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The proud animals have not walked such a path ... nor has the fierce lion passed there

contextId.information: Both phrases mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that a man's wisdom comes from God. AT: "there is a spirit in a man, that is, the breath of the Almighty that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: there is a spirit in a man ... the breath of the Almighty

contextId.information: These mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that he is now ready to speak. His "tongue" speaking represents himself speaking. AT: "I have opened my mouth and I have begun to speak"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I have opened my mouth ... my tongue has spoken in my mouth

contextId.information: These two lines mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that God has made him and so gives authority to what he is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The Spirit of God ... has given me life

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. AT: "God saves people from the grave and from death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: God keeps man's life back from the pit ... his life from crossing over to death

contextId.information: These two lines share similar meanings. The second line intensifies the meaning of the first line. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: If you have sinned ... what do you do to him?

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his fear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: my heart trembles ... it is moved out of its place
